In the one as in the other case, he has the right to display the flag of the United States.

My government maintains, as a principal of recognized international right, that the vessels have not only the faculty to display, wherever they render themselves, the flag of the country where its owners are subjects, but that in general it is a duty for them to display this flag.

This principal will be nevertheless directly combatted by a disposition that would oblige the vessels navigating in the waters of a particular state to display the flag of this state, when these waters are open, as it is the case here, to the foreign navigation.
sense that appears to have to be given to the article 2 of the royal decree of April 30th 1887.

This article has for effect of substituting the flag of the Indpendent State of the Congo to the national flag of the vessel in obliging this one to display at the back the flag of the Congo; it is evident that the flags of two nations can not both be deployed at the same time on the same pole. This deployment would denote, in certain circumstances at least, that the vessel is taken by the nationality which the narrators are placed the highest.
I think that it is a universal use that the flag displayed at the back is that of the nationality of the vessel.
The last clause of the article 2 of the decree from the

30th of april looks as a right of the part of the authorities of the state of the Congo to determine in which conditions the vessels can display their national flag, these conditions being subordinated to the possession of the vessel papers establishing the nationality of the boats.

My government supports that it belongs to each country to determine for itself the conditions of the use of flags aboard its vessels. The rule of the United States is that the vessels of good faith belonging to the citizens of this country have the right, while they are abroad, to display the flag of the United States some being the papers that they possess.
I am in consequence charged by my Government
to protest against the application of the article 2 of the decree from the 30th of april 1887 to the vessels belonging to the citizens of the United States:
1) in that which it obliges these vessels to display at the back the flag of the Independent State of the Congo.The right to display another flag than that of their own nationality is not recognized;
2) in that which the right to enforce their national flag is subordinated to the possession of the vessels papers establishing their nationality.
